summary: autophagy is a multistep process that consists of isolation of cytoplasmic components into double-membrane vesicles that shuttle to lysosomes. it is a catabolic mechanism that enables the removal of damaged or excess cellular organelles and proteins, thereby contributing to cell homeostasis and survival. xLIR motif consists of a short amino acid sequence with a core motif originally described as W/F/YxxI/L/V. this sequence has lately been extended to 6 amino acids to integrate most of the experimentally verified LIRs. we have developed a database, iLIR@viral (http://ilir.uk/virus/), that organizes information on the presence of LIR motifs in viral proteins. a text-mining analysis of the literature allowed us to predict functional LIR motifs in viral proteins that have already been shown to associate with Atg8-family members. iLIR@Viral database ‘Classification’ menu allows the user to look in the database for a specific protein or virus order, family, subfamily, genus, species or common name. the 'Search' menu allows the user to look in the database for a specific protein or virus order, family, subfamily, genus, species or common name. from UniProt across 2569 individual viral species we found that 15,589 of them contain either xLIR or WxxL motifs. 6247 proteins contain both xLIR and WxxL motifs. 129 proteins contain only xLIR motifs. 188 species of bacteriophages belong to 188 species of bacteriophages. but these sequences correspond to false-positive hits as bacteria don't have an autophagy process. xLIR and WxxL patterns in LIRCPs were higher in viruses infecting eukaryotes than in bacteriophages. 45% and 38% of putative LIR motifs matching the WxxL pattern are of F-type and Y-type respectively. similar distribution could be observed for the putative xLIR motifs with a higher variability across families. the protein M2 from influenza A virus is necessary and sufficient for the inhibition of the autophagic degradation of the virus by blocking the fusion between the autophagosomes and lysosomes. the fact that M2 protein has been shown to block the autophagosome-lysosome fusion suggests that it may act as an adaptor protein. the proteins TRS1 from human cytomegalovirus and neurovirulence factor ICP34.5 from human herpesvirus (HSV) both interact with BECN1 via a specific BECN1-binding domain. this interaction is required for the inhibition of autophagosome maturation and fusion with the lysosomes. however, there is no evidence of association between ICP34.5 and LC3 proteins. checking for the presence of LIR motifs revealed a discrepancy. it is possible that the absence of either the xLIR or WxxL motifs in DENV-3 is responsible for its lower affinity to LC3 proteins. viral database is a web resource freely available to the academic community at http://ilir.uk/virus/. the ‘Classification’ menu gives access to the complete list of putative LIR motifs in viral proteins. two virus taxonomic systems have been used to name the species, genus and families of each of the viruses cited in the database. we have used position-specific iterative BLAST to search against the database. by default, the BLAST search runs against all the data available in the database with a default e-value 0.01. however, the user has the possibility to run the BLAST search against a specific category and
